articles.content:
The necessary consequence of man’s right to life is his right to self-defense.
In a civilized society, force may be used only in retaliation and only against
those who initiate its use. All the reasons which make the initiation of
physical force an evil, make the retaliatory use of physical force a moral
imperative.
articles.attribution:
“The Nature of Government,”
The Virtue of Selfishness, 108

articles.content: The individual does possess the right of self-defense and that is the right which he delegates to the government, for the purpose of an orderly, legally defined enforcement.
articles.attribution:
“America’s Persecuted Minority: Big Business,”
Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal, 46

articles.content: A proper government is only a policeman, acting as an agent of man’s self-defense, and, as such, may resort to force only against those who start the use of force.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 183

articles.content:
Just as an individual has the right of self-defense, so has a free country if
attacked. But this does not give its government the right to draft men into
military service—which is the most blatantly statist violation of a man’s
right to his own life.
articles.attribution:
“The Roots of War,”
For the New Intellectual, 40
